prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation is about splitting bills after a single incident where the girlfriend had to pay for takeout.

First, the guy and his girlfriend live together. He's paying all the bills because she's only working part-time. Then they go out for takeout, he forgets his wallet, so she has to pay. She reacts negatively, which upsets him. Now he's considering making her pay some bills even though she can't afford much, just for principle.

Hmm, the main points here are about fairness and expectations in a relationship. The guy didn't mind paying everything before, but this one incident made him change his mind. Is he justified in wanting her to start contributing, even if it's a small amount? Well, he's the one earning more, so maybe he can afford to pay everything. But the issue is her reaction. She acted upset and maybe taken aback, which he found offensive. 

But wait, maybe the problem is that he's overreacting to a single event. The takeout was under $40, which isn't a huge amount. He's using this as a catalyst to change the financial arrangement, but maybe the real issue is that he's feeling resentful about paying all the bills when she's working part-time. However, he's the one who was okay with it before. Now he's using this incident as a reason to make her contribute, even if it's out of principle. 

Is it fair for him to make her pay some bills if she can't afford much? If he's the one earning more, maybe he should continue paying the majority, but maybe they should have a discussion about splitting expenses. But the problem is that he's making her pay not just because she can contribute, but because of her reaction to the takeout. That seems more like a reaction to her attitude rather than a financial necessity. 

Also, in relationships, splitting bills can be a sensitive topic. If he's been paying everything up to now, suddenly changing the rules might cause more stress. She might not be ready to take on that responsibility, especially if she's part-time. Maybe the issue is more about his reaction to her attitude than the actual financial contribution.

So, the question is whether the author is in the wrong. If he's making her pay because of her reaction to a one-time event, that might be unfair. Especially if her part-time income isn't enough to contribute much. But if he feels that the arrangement should be more balanced, maybe that's his right. But the key point is that he's using a single incident to justify changing the financial arrangement. That could be seen as holding a grudge or being petty. 

So, considering all that, maybe the author is in the wrong because he's overreacting to a minor incident and changing the terms of their agreement without considering her financial situation. He should have discussed the financial expectations from the start rather than waiting for this trigger. Therefore, answer A (Yes, the author is in the wrong).
